Topic.Title: CES 2013: what to expect (hint: Tegra 4 an Huawei)

Message.Msg: "Always having a finger in the smartphone market, Huawei is set to release their first Windows Phone 8 device." "Huawei will be the fourth manufacturer to launch a Windows Phone 8 smartphone when it launches its Ascend W1." Take a look at the specs for Huawei's new Windows Phone 8 Ascend W1. Google this : Huawei Ascend W1 - Full phone specifications - GSM Arena OS : Microsoft Windows Phone 8 Chipset : Qualcomm Snapdragon S4 CPU : Dual-core 1.2 GHz Krait GPU : Adreno 225 HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA! nvidia lost yet another one -- to Qualcomm!

Topic.Title: CES 2013: what to expect (hint: Tegra 4 an Huawei)

Message.Msg: So Master? If this was a game of Olympic baseball. And Team Qualcomm was playing little nvidia. The game would be called-off. And Qualcomm would win, right? Due to the "slaughter rule". I thought so. From Wikipedia: Mercy rule - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia "A mercy rule, also well known by the slightly less polite term "slaughter rule", brings a sports event to an early end when one team has a very large and presumably insurmountable lead over the other team. It is called the mercy rule because it spares the losing team the humiliation of suffering a more formal loss, and denies the winning team the satisfaction thereof, and prevents running up the score, a generally discouraged practice in which the opponent continues to score beyond the point when the game has become out of hand. The mercy rule is most common in games such as baseball or softball, where there is no game clock and play could theoretically continue forever, although it is also used in sports such as hockey and American football."

Topic.Title: CES 2013: what to expect (hint: Tegra 4 an Huawei)

Message.Msg: Good point, Best. About the industry needing a "slaughter rule". Separately, it looks like Huawei might be winning a Best of CES award. For their Ascend W1 Win8 smartphone. Yep. The fourth manufacturer on the planet to launch a Qualcomm-powered Windows Phone 8.

I thought so." From Wikipedia: Mercy rule - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia "A mercy rule, also well known by the slightly less polite term "slaughter rule", brings a sports event to an early end when one team has a very large and presumably insurmountable lead over the other team. It is called the mercy rule because it spares the losing team the humiliation of suffering a more formal loss, and denies the winning team the satisfaction thereof, and prevents running up the score, a generally discouraged practice in which the opponent continues to score beyond the point when the game has become out of hand. The mercy rule is most common in games such as baseball or softball, where there is no game clock and play could theoretically continue forever, although it is also used in sports such as hockey and American football." So how would this work, Best? If one team -- say Team Qualcomm -- sold 96,500,000 smartphone processors. During the first half of 2012. According to EE Times. And the other little team -- nvidia -- sold only 2.4 million. Would they be put into different leagues or something? So as to avoid the little team always losing due to the "slaughter rule".

Message.Title: More deals than we know! Like this one
Message.Msg: Viva Barcelona! The Barcelona Supercomputer Center is building Mont-Blanc, the world's most energy efficient supercomputer by using NVIDIA's (NASDAQ: NVDA ) Tegra 3 mobile processor over the typical Intel Xeon found in supercomputers. For comparison, the typical Xeon processor consumes 50 to 100 watts of energy, where each Tegra will be tuned to consume just 4 watts. Although the project is using off-the-shelf materials, it's not an off-the-shelf initiative. Practically every piece of code written for Intel x86-based architecture needs to be repurposed in order to take advantage of Tegra 3's ARM-based architecture. For data centers, this is great news, because whatever is learned and developed during the process will be openly shared with the community. It's no wonder the sycophants populate this board like a disease. They see their monopoly falling fast! Tell me who saw thhis use for tegra chips coming?

Topic.Title: NVDA in apple mac products?

Message.Msg: A matter of fact NVDA cards are in all the 15 in mac books pro and retina laptops. The fastest growing laptops.

Topic.Title: More deals than we know! Like this one

Message.Msg: Your pumping script is badly out of date. Those nvidia parts for the Mont-Blanc Barcelona Supercomputer Center were kicked to the curb in November. Yep. nvidia tegra parts are out -- and Samsung's Exynos 5250 superior chips are in. BSC Selects Samsung Exynos Processor Over Nvidia Tegra [11/19/2012 10:10 PM] by Anton Shilov The Mont-Blanc European project has selected the Samsung Exynos platform as the building block for powering its first integrated low power high performance computing (HPC) prototype. Previously, the Mont-Blanc project was co-developed by Barcelona Supercomputing Center and Nvidia Corp., but it looks like the latter is no longer a part of the project. The aim of Mont-Blanc project is to design a new type of computer architecture capable of setting future global HPC standards, built from today’s energy efficient solutions used in embedded and mobile devices. The Samsung Exynos 5250 is built on 32nm low-power HKMG (high-K netal gate) technology, and features two 1.70GHz ARM Cortex-A15 architecture cores plus an integrated ARM Mali-T604 GPU for increased performance density and energy efficiency. It has been featured and market proven in consumer and mobile devices such as Samsung Chromebook and Google’s Nexus 10. This will be the first use of an embedded mobile SoC in HPC, which enables the Mont-Blanc project to explore the challenges and benefits of deeply integrated energy-efficient processors and GPU accelerators, compared to traditional homogeneous multicore systems, and heterogeneous CPU + external GPU architectures. "The Exynos 5 Dual packs the most powerful ARM processors with a programmable GPU in a low-power mobile device that would normally be in someone’s pocket and running on a battery. Its performance density, energy efficiency, and low market price make it an extraordinary building block for prototyping a new generation of HPC systems," said Alex Ramirez, coordinator of the Mont-Blanc project. During the first year of activities, Mont-Blanc has focused on deploying successfully an HPC system software stack and full-scale scientific applications on ARM platforms, proving that ARM-based architectures are feasible alternatives for HPC. Now the efforts gear towards integration of the Exynos platform on a HPC solution, and software exploitation of the embedded GPU. "Previously, the Mont-Blanc project was co-developed by Barcelona Supercomputing Center and Nvidia Corp., but it looks like the latter is no longer a part of the project." { CLINK ! .... Clink clink clink bink bink } There goes another big tegra order -- Kicked to the curb.

Topic.Title: NAZ UP - NVDA DOWN

Message.Msg: as much as the pumper boyz here absolutely dread the words 'total reachable market', the street is not fooled. Can never get into aapl nor samsung, #3 tablet is cheap only, #4 tablet is for sharing the wealth, not enough IP to integrate their way into the huge feature phone and low end phone market, nvda has the same problem as txn and motorola, Tegra is dead in the long run. BTW, very quietly, no press releases, no CES, no public bragging, brcm has captured 15% of the Android phone market, with much more to come this year as Samsung is just starting to ramp quite a few more phones on brcm's integrated solutions. And brcm is not really into china yet. Now that is a business plan. Jen/nvda has no viable business plan for Tegras. The street is not fooled.

Topic.Title: NAZ UP - NVDA DOWN

Message.Msg: at this point, nvda is fooling no one on their Tegras. In the beginning, nvda did get into the Samsung tablet and Tegra was actually ahead of aapl in processor development. Now both Samsung and aapl are ahead of nvda. And txn's exit really spelled out what it takes to win in the mobile market. One must ask: is Jen that much of a fool or he can't just accept reality? It will take the BOD to stop him, but I doubt they will act until Jen has flushed away all the shareholders' money.

Topic.Title: NAZ UP - NVDA DOWN

Message.Msg: Nvidia never had a viable business plan for SOC market. Icera buy is a complete flop. Remember this doozy from Nvidia press release "The transaction is expected to be slightly dilutive on an operating basis through the first half of calendar 2012, and accretive on an operating basis in the second half of calendar 2012." Mike Rayfield quit this business while a 50% growth was being touted - why? TXN and Freescale quit mobile SOC market for a reason, they don't like losing money like Nvidia does. Apple, Samsung, Qualcomm, Intel, Mediatek will duke it out for 99% of market share. Nvidia will continue flogging for the remaining 1% market share in mobile SOC. 2012 was a terrible year for Nvidia, stock lost 13% as compared to Nasdaq which gained 15% Nvidia is headed for 7th straight Red day closing 2012 and heading into CES. If this does not raise flags for longs then nothing else will.

Topic.Title: NAZ UP - NVDA DOWN

Message.Msg: at this point, what it takes to play in the mobile market is an open book: 1. intc spending $1.2B for a 'cheap' radio, 2. qcom paying $3.2B for Athero/wifi 3. txn's and Freescale's reasons for exiting 4. Samsung buying a wifi company 5. nvda buying Icera 6. brcm's very quietly getting a 15% market share for Andoid phones, and that's even before the mass ramp of many models at Samsung in '13. And that's pointing the way of both how to do business at numero dos and how huge the less than bleeding edge market is, if one has the IP to integrate into it. 7. #1 &2 will always use their own processors for their high end, amzn willl stick with their very successful cheap, goog will always spread the wealth - all thereby limiting the addressable TAM. 8. brcm will finally sell a standalone 28nm LTE (my guess is they already have design win at aapl or samsung or even both). Brcm had played it very close to the vest in mobile the last few years. But in their last analyst's day a month ago, they finally spend two hours on a presentation and spilled the beans. For those investing in the mobile space, you owe it to yourself to listen to that to get an idea of how brcm is mounting a successful attack of the huge and fast growing market.

Topic.Title: NAZ UP - NVDA DOWN

Topic.Title: NAZ UP - NVDA DOWN

Message.Msg: "Nvidia never had a viable business plan for SOC market. " Considering the growth I would say it's viable and there isn't any sign it's slowing for NVIDIA as they pick up more market share. I would argue that Qualcomm's strategy was just as one off and organic. "Icera buy is a complete flop. Remember this doozy from Nvidia press release "The transaction is expected to be slightly dilutive on an operating basis through the first half of calendar 2012, and accretive on an operating basis in the second half of calendar 2012."" The project is late - this is true but so we will have t see until late 2013 to see if this statement holds true. "Mike Rayfield quit this business while a 50% growth was being touted - why? " Nobody knows - did he quite or was he asked to leave? "TXN and Freescale quit mobile SOC market for a reason, they don't like losing money like Nvidia" I don't think you can compare NVIDIA to these two companies. TXN has had very little consumer presence since it's calculators. Both have weak balance sheets (esp FSL) and FSL has an extremely weak cash flow situation going on (OCF - is even really weak). So, exiting made sense financial. NVIDIA financial profile and marketing constitution blow the other two out of the water. NVIDIA has great brand recognition, marketing, and financials to allow it to grow and withstand any setbacks in this venture. You simply can't put NVIDIA in the same category. "Apple, Samsung, Qualcomm, Intel, Mediatek will duke it out for 99% of market share. Nvidia will continue flogging for the remaining 1% market share in mobile SOC." Conjecture with a heavy twist of pessimistic sentiment - this is not what the current trend depicts and Intel has yet to even make a dent. "2012 was a terrible year for Nvidia, stock lost 13% as compared to Nasdaq which gained 15%" Can't argue with that but as far as technicals - however I've been burned more with momentum buys. "Nvidia is headed for 7th straight Red day closing 2012 and heading into CES. If this does not raise flags for longs then nothing else will." I did expect it to be up today, but that being said, and I've said this before, I think the drop in the price is macro and reading into CES is a miserable gamble - none of us know but I'd rather gamble on the side of positive considering what I have heard earlier from the company. It wouldn't surprise me if the company is holding back press releases until the budget gets figured out as any positive news would be muted and forgotten. Waiting until there are more buyers would accelerate the movement - most tech stocks seem to be in this holding pattern right now. Good luck...

Conversely, if the stock sells off, 11.80 would be a good entry point. Nvidia needs not only to execute well on its plan but also the plan needs to be competitive against Qualcomm. Topic.Title: MA-50 12.19 will not be broken

Message.Msg: I think the moves they've made will not only keep them but make them more competitive with QCOMM. There is plenty of market share to be taken and the addition of 30% - 40% put profitability in sight. Another point that everybody seems to be dismissing is that NVIDIA has pipelines in other markets it can benefit from. The "PC is dead" mantra is way oversold and dismisses the benefit a company in this industry has in the mobile space. I think there are plenty of points of differentiation here to further accelerate growth in mobile and their other markets.

Seriously.

Message.Title: I Like The New Nvidia!
Message.Msg: I am a swing trader now, but 3 to 4 years ago I was a day trader. I've followed and traded Nvidia for the last 4 years.So I have some sense of this company and it's stock. The introduction of a dividend and the resumption or the threat of the stock buyback has brought a level of stability to the stock that I like. In addition, Nvidia has approached a level of critical mass in Geforce Graphics with 2012 GPU market share gains along with Tesla and Quadro growth and profit margins. NVX and Gaming Grid initiatives have a lot of potential too. Tegra is also approaching critical mass. I suspect that by this time next year Tegra revenue will be at least 50% above this year's and we Nvidia will be talking in terms of number of design wins rather than individual wins just like they track their PC discrete market wins. In other words Nvidia will become a bet on particular markets like tablets and smartphones or severs, etc. rather than the latest rumor on the internet. Icera modems should also come into play next year. JMHO, and by the Way HAPPY NEW YEAR

Topic.Title: I Like The New Nvidia!

Message.Msg: So where will the PPS be in a year, you think? And where will annualized share earnings be? I like the new, more stable stock price, too, just wish the shares were trading in the $20s, not the $12s...
